history.content: A student may be able to answer, but for immediate help please contact the ERSO/hiring people mentioned in the offer/acceptance emails

Hi! I TAed for 61B for the past four semesters. From my personal experience, I've always paid for the semester and then gotten an EFT reimbursement later. The reimbursement tends to come pretty late after the semester has started. (Like last semester in Fall 2015, I got reimbursed at the beginning of October.)

I'm not 100% about this part, but I think you should just pay tuition so that your registration doesn't get blocked/fines don't get imposed just in case. Nicole makes a good point about asking the human resources department for more certain answers. :)

To add:

The tuition reimbursement only covers the in-state portion, I can't be certain how the job counts for residency thought. 

Most undergrads directly pay tution and get reimbursed, though you may be able to not pay it -- any remaining CARS balance will be deducted from your reimbursement. If you did want to avoid paying tution you usually have about 1 month before the school gets mad and gives you a block on anything - and I've heard it's possible to have tution waived instead of refunded, but have never done it myself.

Note that for grad students this process is different, and for grad students the tution is waived - so you only pay the remaining student fees.

children.subject: Oh right, in case anyone else was wondering: I talked to the Residency Affairs office and they said that the financial independence requirement waiver only applies to graduate students.

Related - what happens if you're an out-of-state undergrad serving as a 20-hour TA? Is the financial independence requirement for residency waived as stated here?

(Relevant quote: "The financial independence requirement will not be a factor in determining residence status for graduate student instructors ... who are employed at UC for 49% or more of full time ... in the term for which resident classification is sought.")

history.content:
If we were selected as a 20 hr TA, how does the tuition waiver work?

Do I still pay tuition for the semester and then will be reimbursed later? Or do I just not pay and the fee will be waived?
history.subject: 20 hr TA Tuition Waiver
